description:
Clostridium merdae is an anaerobic, gram-positive, spore-forming bacterium that was first isolated from human fecal samples. It is a member of the genus Clostridium, which is known for containing several pathogenic species.

C. merdae is a strictly anaerobic bacterium, meaning it can only grow and thrive in the absence of oxygen. It is a spore-forming species, which allows it to survive in harsh environmental conditions and resist various physical and chemical stresses.

The cells of C. merdae are typically rod-shaped and can vary in size, usually ranging from 0.5 to 1.0 micrometers in width and 2 to 6 micrometers in length. The bacterium is non-motile and does not produce any visible pigments.

Phylogenetically, C. merdae is closely related to other Clostridium species, but it has distinct phenotypic and genomic characteristics that distinguish it from its closest relatives. The bacterium is believed to be a part of the normal gut microbiota in humans and may play a role in various gastrointestinal processes, though its specific functions and potential pathogenic properties are still under investigation.
